e8twlax.Author: [deleted]
e8twlax.Text:
Why 2019. It’s been working as a currency for years until last years’ speculators over-ran the network. We use it daily as a POS. It was cheaper than Visa until last year but now it’s back and if Segwit and Lightning are implemented like the developers are working on, it’ll be the best POS in the world. 
And I refuse to run a btrash node. It’s all spam transactions and too large. 

Innovation around 1mb blocks which is 4mb with Segwit and more with Lightning is what we needed.

e8sbsca.Author: Neveragain646
e8sbsca.Text: Macro economic forces will drive crypto demand. The economic crisis was THE reason Bitcoin began climbing. The macro economic factors aren't favourable at the moment. Normal economy is doing good. So there's no reason for anyone to invest in crypto right now. That's why there's no interest whatsoever. Once economic recession kicks in, you'll see people searching for alternative ways to invest. Problem is, banks have taken measurements after the crisis, so it's unlikely a new banking crisis emerges. We have to wait till something happens. Imagine something like Lira downfall happens with the dollar. It won't happen so soon, but it would be ideal for btc. You would see a major shift from dollars to btc, topping the ath of btc for sure. The question is not if a big shift will happen, but when...

e8sporj.Author: oogally
e8sporj.Text:
Why are you into bitcoin?  For me, it's a chance to hold hard money, secure, and inflation limited, which can be transmitted anywhere in the world in ~10 minutes.  Are the world's reserve banks going to suddenly stop printing money and return to sound economic policy?  Is hyperinflation in troubled economies going to suddenly stop due to the benevolence of their leadership?  Is SHA256 encryption about to be cracked?  Those are the things which would worry me about holding bitcoin.  These days, especially with deteriorating economic conditions, my bitcoin is letting me sleep like a baby.  
  
Sure, we may have another year of lackluster price performance, but no fundamentals have changed.  If anything, we're closer to halving the inflation rate again, we have improved scaling in the protocol and layer 2, and solid support for a higher price floor that has held for a year now.  I'm a patient guy and in the long run, this is the investment I'm least concerned with.

e8t9bep.Author: xelephonte
e8t9bep.Text:
“Why are you into bitcoin?  For me, it's a chance to hold hard money, secure, and inflation limited.”

Oogally that theory was valid until the hard fork of Bitcoin Cash which basically imposes that when supply of a particular coin is exhausted, developers can just create a hard fork to generate a new supply of that coin. With Bitcoin Cash, Bitcoin’s supply virtually doubled. Bitcoin Cash is identical to Bitcoin in code with the exception of block size limit. That’s what makes cryptocurrency a precarious asset and form of investment. There are far too many coins and hard forks in existence. Why does Bitcoin Gold and Bitcoin Silver even exist other than serving as scams? The whole idea of “finite supply” is contradictory when hard forks can be erected. Sure, Bitcoin Cash at $420 today hasn’t taken away too much from Bitcoin’s true value, not to mention it’s impractical to interpolate Bitcoin’s price today if BCH, BGold and Silver didn’t exist. I assume BTC would be in the same ballpark. But, remember when Bitcoin was $17K, BCash was $4K taking off a much more significant chunk of Bitcoin’s true value. And this will be more concerning with Bitcoin’s fate when the crypto market is in the trillions. Developers will get greedy and erect more hard forks to further distribute more wealth off Bitcoin. So, if you’re a firm believer of Bitcoin’s finite supply, you’re vastly misinformed since hard fork exist and will continue to exist in greater numbers.

e8su2ob.Author: aaj094
e8su2ob.Text:
Your thinking was flawed. Even in theory, it is impossible for bitcoin to just keep steadily rising and reach the steady state of gold market cap. Reason is that doing so would not facilitate distribution of the coins more widely and thus cannot make the higher price level sustainable. In other words, too few people will be sitting on too much bitcoin wealth if such a continuous appreciation occurred. 

This is the main reason for the peaks and deep valleys of bitcoin price enroute to the steady state. The price fall is far from worrisome. Infact it was only to be expected albeit timing your sell to take advantage of this pre ordained price mechanism is not easy at all. So HoDL.

e8tbs4a.Author: aaj094
e8tbs4a.Text:
The shitcoins that these forks were are slowly but surely dying out. Some can have minor use cases and others may continue with the use case of gambling that sustains most crypto shitcoins.

The pristine Bitcoin blockchain is one that will always have a distinct identity by virtue of being the first and also the most secure crypto. It also benefits from the network advantage. Increasing number of forks and coins might be a concern for any of the other myriad coins but this factor does not bother me in the least about diluting the value Bitcoin itself to any great degree. You can see this at work right now with 1800+ coins on coinmarketcap and yet the market piling into bitcoin and raising the dominance ratio throughout this year. 

I know this ratio was once 90% but that was before the altcoin market had any kind of mature existence at all. The fact that the dominance ratio again climbed after an alt craze like last dec shows that Bitcoin has an absolute special place within crypto and won't be susceptible to dilution by any fork or altcoin.

There is also the point that any coin that can even hope to get past the network advantage barrier must be a fork of Bitcoin and if this is the case then again holding Bitcoin is safe as you would gain ownership of the forks as well and thus lose nothing even from the dilution.

e8tpydn.Author: Nursing_guy
e8tpydn.Text:
"identical to Bitcoin in code with the exception of block size limit."

That difference, which you so casually disregard, makes it radically different from Bitcoin. So much so that they will never be able to be spent on each other's networks and that some will never accept substitution.

It's like saying two one hundred dollar bills are the same except one was printed in my garage. One of them simply isn't a 100 dollar bill

e8tbhgi.Author: oogally
e8tbhgi.Text:
Fair points.  I view at least 99% of alts as scams, and I'm not too concerned if others want to get wrapped up in them or not.  Bitcoin had a pretty unique organic genesis which can't really be recreated today, so there's that too.  
  
In terms of forks, I held BTC before the BCH fork, so my 1BTC became 1BTC + 1BCH.  Still the same fraction of ownership of the available supply - no wealth magically created or destroyed.
